## User Story
As an operator, I want refresh token revocation to persist across restarts and work in multi-instance deployments so that logout/revocation actually invalidates sessions reliably.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Replace in-memory denylist with persistent session store (Redis or PostgreSQL)
- [ ] Create session/token table with fields: token_jti, user_id, issued_at, expires_at, revoked_at, rotated_from_jti (optional)
- [ ] Implement TTL/automatic cleanup for expired tokens
- [ ] Track token rotation (link new refresh token to old one it replaced)
- [ ] Update  to mark tokens as revoked in persistent store
- [ ] Update  to check revocation status before issuing new tokens
- [ ] Update middleware to query persistent store for revocation checks
- [ ] Add migration script for database schema changes
- [ ] Performance: revocation check must add <10ms latency per request
- [ ] Documentation: update README with session store configuration

## Technical Notes
- **Redis option:** Use Redis with TTL for automatic expiration, good for high-performance scenarios
- **PostgreSQL option:** Use table with  + periodic cleanup job, simpler if already using Postgres
- **Hybrid option:** Redis for hot revocation checks, Postgres for audit/history
- **JTI (JWT ID) usage:** Each token needs unique jti claim for revocation tracking
- **Rotation tracking:** Store  to detect replay attacks with old tokens
- **Environment variables:** Add  (Redis connection string or DB URL)

## Assignment
Type: backend — will be handled by backend-dev agent

## Size
M (2–5 days)
title: [backend] Replace in-memory refresh-token revocation with persistent session store
